questions.text: Which of the following can be used as an intravenous induction agent? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Propofol

 

Explanation:

 

Propofol is a short-acting intravenous anesthetic agent widely used for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia. It has a rapid onset and produces a smooth and quick recovery, but can cause hypotension and respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic. It is not used as an intravenous induction agent for general anesthesia. Instead, it's used for regional anesthesia like epidural or nerve blocks. When administered systemically, it can be toxic, especially to the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

 

Option C. Dexmedetomidine: Dexmedetomidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It provides sedation without causing respiratory depression. Although it is used for sedation in the ICU and for certain procedures, it's not typically used as a primary induction agent for general anesthesia.

 

Option D. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. It is used to reverse neuromuscular blockade (from non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers) at the end of a surgery. It is not used as an induction agent for anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Propofol is a widely used intravenous induction agent for general anesthesia due to its rapid onset and smooth recovery profile.

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present
Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present

questions.text: During resuscitation, when is the given position? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present

 

This is the recovery position, indicated in post-op patients who are awake or drowsy or unconscious with pulse and breathing present to prevent aspiration of any secretions or vomit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent: Means the patient is in cardiac arrest and requires immediate resuscitation measures.

 

Option B. Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent: This is respiratory arrest and rescue breathing or bag-valve-mask ventilation should be initiated to maintain breathing of patient.

 

Option D. Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present: This seems very theoretical because with a lack of circulation, breathing isn’t feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for an unconscious patient who has a pulse and is breathing to prevent aspiration and maintain airway patency.

questions.text: A patient was undergoing surgery under general anesthesia. For intubation, 90 mg of rocuronium was given, but the anesthesiologist was unable to intubate the patient. What is the drug given for immediate reversal of the neuromuscular blockade? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sugammadex

 

Sugammadex is specifically designed to reverse the effects of rocuronium and vecuronium, which are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents used during anesthesia. Rocuronium works by blocking acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis. Sugammadex, a γ-cyclodextrin compound, encapsulates the rocuronium molecules, effectively removing them from the neuromuscular junction. This action results in the immediate reversal of muscle paralysis, allowing the patient to regain normal muscle function. Sugammadex is unique because it can rapidly reverse the effects of rocuronium, even if the drug was administered only moments earlier, which is crucial in situations where intubation fails and the patient needs to recover quickly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is used to reverse non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like rocuronium, but it is not effective immediately after the drug has been administered. Neostigmine works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, thereby increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction to outcompete the blocking agent. However, for neostigmine to be effective, a significant amount of the neuromuscular blocking agent must have already dissociated from the receptors, which typically happens toward the end of the surgery, not immediately after administration.

 

Option C. Glycopyrrolate: Glycopyrrolate is often used in conjunction with neostigmine to counteract the muscarinic side effects of increased acetylcholine, such as bradycardia. However, glycopyrrolate itself does not reverse neuromuscular blockade and cannot be used to immediately counteract the effects of rocuronium.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine, like glycopyrrolate, is used to mitigate the side effects of cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine. It does not reverse neuromuscular blockade directly and is not effective in immediately reversing the effects of rocuronium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the specific and immediate antidote for the reversal of rocuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade. It is unique in its ability to rapidly and effectively reverse paralysis even shortly after rocuronium administration, making it the drug of choice in emergency situations where rapid recovery of muscle function is required.

questions.text: Identify the mask in the image below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-rebreathing mask

 

The oxygen delivery device shown in the image above is a non-rebreathing mask (NRBM).

 

Non-rebreathing mask (NRBM):

  • The non-rebreathing mask provides high concentrations of oxygen. It features a reservoir bag attached to it, which helps in providing a high flow of oxygen.
  • The mask has one-way valves that prevent exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring that only oxygen is inhaled.
  • The maximum FiO2 given by an NRBM is approximately 80%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: A Venturi mask is designed to deliver a precise oxygen concentration. It has interchangeable valves that regulate the amount of oxygen and ambient air mix, providing specific FiO2 levels. It is typically used when controlled oxygen therapy is required.

 

 

 

Option B. Hudson mask: The Hudson mask, also known as a simple face mask, delivers oxygen concentrations ranging from 40% to 60%. It does not have a reservoir bag and is less precise in delivering a specific oxygen concentration compared to the Venturi mask.

 

 

Option C. Nebulizer mask: A nebulizer mask is used to deliver aerosolized medications (such as bronchodilators) to patients. It is attached to a nebulizer machine, which converts liquid medication into a fine mist for inhalation. This mask is not primarily used for oxygen delivery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask (NRBM) is an oxygen delivery device that provides high concentrations of oxygen, up to approximately 80%, and is characterized by a reservoir bag and one-way valves to ensure the inhalation of high-purity oxygen.

questions.text:
What are the indicators that suggest CPR is of high quality? (INICET May 2023)

 

1. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute

2. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute

3. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm

4. Allow chest recoil
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

 

Explanation:

 

High-Quality CPR Indicators:

 

1. Chest Compression Rate: Chest compressions should be performed at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.

 

3. Depth of Compression: Compressions should have a depth of 5-6 centimeters (2-2.4 inches).

 

4. Chest Recoil: It is essential to allow the chest to fully recoil after each compression to ensure adequate filling of the heart between compressions. If an advanced airway, such as an endotracheal tube or supraglottic airway device, is in place, the recommended ventilation rate is 10 breaths per minute.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 3 only: While a compression depth of 5-6 cm is correct, a breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not part of the indicators for high-quality CPR.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4: Although chest compression rate, depth, and recoil are correct indicators, the breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not recommended for high-quality CPR.

 

Option D. 1 only: While the correct chest compression rate is part of high-quality CPR, other factors like compression depth and chest recoil are also crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.

choices.text: To perform chest tube insertion for pneumothorax
To establish central venous access in an emergency
To secure the airway through endotracheal intubation
To perform cardiac defibrillation in cardiac arrest

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department in severe respiratory distress. On arrival, he is unable to speak in full sentences, and his oxygen saturation is 82% on room air. He rapidly becomes unresponsive, with worsening hypoxia despite non-invasive ventilation attempts. You are called to assist the Emergency Medical Officer in management of this patient. The image below shows the instruments available to you in the emergency cart. What is the primary use of these instruments in the context of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) To secure the airway through endotracheal intubation

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments displayed in the image are components of an airway cart, which is essential in managing a compromised airway, particularly in emergency and anesthesia settings. These tools include laryngoscopes, endotracheal tubes, and other airway adjuncts that facilitate intubation—a procedure where a tube is inserted into the trachea to maintain an open airway. In this patient’s case, rapid deterioration of respiratory function necessitates securing the airway to prevent hypoxia, which can be life-threatening. Endotracheal intubation is the definitive intervention to stabilize the patient’s breathing in such critical scenarios.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) To perform chest tube insertion for pneumothorax: Chest tube insertion involves different equipment such as thoracostomy trays and is used specifically for draining air or fluid from the pleural space, not for airway management.

 

 

Thoracostomy trays

 

Option B) To establish central venous access in an emergency: Central venous access requires a central line kit and is used to administer medications, fluids, or for monitoring central venous pressure, unrelated to airway management.

 

 

Central line kit

 

Option D) To perform cardiac defibrillation in cardiac arrest: Cardiac defibrillation requires a defibrillator and pads, used to restore normal heart rhythm in cases of cardiac arrest, and does not involve the equipment shown in the image.

 

 

Defibrillator and pads

 

Educational Objective:

 

The instruments shown are primarily used for airway management, particularly endotracheal intubation, which is crucial in maintaining ventilation in patients experiencing respiratory failure or during anesthesia. Prompt and appropriate use of these tools can significantly improve patient outcomes in emergency scenarios involving compromised airways.

questions.text: At what level does the spinal cord end in adults? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1-L2

 

Explanation:

 

Termination of the Spinal Cord:

 

  • Anatomy: The spinal cord terminates at a region called the conus medullaris.
  • Details: Below the conus medullaris, a bundle of spinal nerve roots continues downward, which is called the cauda equina (meaning "horse's tail" in Latin) due to its appearance.
  • Adult Spinal Cord End: The lower end of the spinal cord in adults is at the lower border of L1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L3-L4: This is incorrect as the spinal cord in adults does not extend to this level. This level is generally where lumbar punctures are performed to avoid the spinal cord.

 

Option C. T12-L1: This is slightly higher than the actual end of the spinal cord in adults. The spinal cord terminates at L1-L2, not T12-L1.

 

Option D. L2-L3: This is incorrect as well because the spinal cord ends at L1-L2 in adults, not extending to L2-L3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The spinal cord in adults terminates at the lower border of L1, at the region called the conus medullaris, with the cauda equina continuing downward from this point.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1414

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, it was observed that there was a sudden decrease in etCO2  to 8 mm Hg, SpO2 was 90%, BP dropped to 80/50 mm Hg and peak airway pressure was observed to be 18 mm Hg. Which of the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CO2 embolism

 

Explanation:

 

In the scenario described, a sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 (etCO2) to 8 mm Hg, along with a drop in blood pressure (BP) to 80/50 mm Hg and oxygen saturation (SpO2) to 90%, but with normal peak airway pressure (18 mm Hg), strongly suggests a CO2 embolism. During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used for insufflation to create a pneumoperitoneum, which can occasionally enter a blood vessel and cause a CO2 embolism. This event leads to a rapid decrease in etCO2 due to reduced return of CO2 to the lungs, hypoxemia, and cardiovascular collapse. The normal peak airway pressures help differentiate it from other causes of acute respiratory distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax, or collapsed lung, could occur due to barotrauma from mechanical ventilation or surgical complications. However, it typically causes an increase in peak airway pressures due to increased resistance to ventilation. The absence of increased peak airway pressures makes pneumothorax less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Endobronchial Intubation: Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube is inserted too far and intubates one of the main bronchi, typically the right main bronchus. This can lead to hypoventilation of one lung, causing a decrease in etCO2 and SpO2. However, peak airway pressures might be higher due to one-lung ventilation, which was not observed here.

 

Option D. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm involves the constriction of the muscles in the walls of the bronchioles, leading to narrowed airways. This would usually present with an increase in peak airway pressures due to the narrowed airways, which is not consistent with the normal peak airway pressures reported in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During laparoscopic surgery, the sudden onset of hypotension, hypoxemia, and a significant decrease in etCO2 with normal peak airway pressures suggests a CO2 embolism, a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desflurane

 

  • Desflurane is a highly pungent gas, and its use for inhalational induction can lead to airway irritation, coughing, breath-holding, and even laryngospasm, especially in pediatric patients.
  • Therefore, desflurane is not typically used as an induction agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: Due to its pleasant odor and rapid onset, Halothane was historically a popular choice for inhalational induction in children. However, concerns regarding hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias have reduced its usage in modern practice.

 

Option B. Sevoflurane: Sevoflurane is one of the most commonly used agents for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its non-irritating nature and rapid kinetics.

 

Option D. Nitrous Oxide: Nitrous oxide is often used as an adjunct to other inhalational anesthetics for both induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It has a rapid onset and is generally well-tolerated by pediatric patients. It can be used for inhalational induction, especially in combination with more potent agents like sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desflurane is not typically used for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients due to its pungent nature, which can cause significant airway irritation and laryngospasm.

choices.text: Second gas effect
To provide adequate analgesia
Because air is more expensive than oxygen

questions.text: Why is 100% oxygen given after nitrous oxide is stopped during the emergence from anesthesia? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Diffusion hypoxia

 

Explanation:


After discontinuing nitrous oxide (N2O), the gas can rapidly diffuse from the blood into the alveoli, which may dilute the oxygen levels in the lungs and lead to a condition known as diffusion hypoxia. To prevent this drop in oxygen levels, 100% oxygen is administered to ensure that the patient remains adequately oxygenated as they emerge from anesthesia.

 

Other options:


Option A. Second gas effect: This effect is related to the rapid uptake of N2O enhancing the concentration of other anesthetic gases but is not the reason for administering 100% oxygen after stopping N2O.


Option C. To provide adequate analgesia: Oxygen is not administered for analgesia purposes, making this option incorrect.


Option D. Because air is more expensive than oxygen: This is not a valid reason for using 100% oxygen in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Administering 100% oxygen after stopping nitrous oxide is crucial to prevent diffusion hypoxia and ensure proper oxygenation during the patient's recovery from anesthesia.

questions.text: Arrange the following anaethesia agents on the basis of their potency.(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methoxyflurane>Halothane>Isoflurane>Nitrous oxide

 

Explanation:

 

Potency of Anesthetic Agents:

  • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is measured by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC). The MAC value is inversely proportional to the potency; lower MAC values indicate higher potency.

 

MAC Values:

  • Methoxyflurane: 0.16
  • Halothane: 0.75
  • Isoflurane: 1.4
  • Nitrous oxide: 104

 

Order of Potency (from most potent to least potent):

  • Methoxyflurane: With the lowest MAC of 0.16, it is the most potent agent.
  • Halothane: With a MAC of 0.75, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane but more potent than Isoflurane and Nitrous oxide.
  • Isoflurane: With a MAC of 1.4, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane and Halothane but more potent than Nitrous oxide.
  • Nitrous oxide: With the highest MAC of 104, it is the least potent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane > Methoxyflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide has the highest MAC and is the least potent, while Methoxyflurane is the most potent.

 

Option C. Methoxyflurane > Isoflurane > Halothane > Nitrous oxide: Incorrect, as Halothane is more potent than Isoflurane.

 

Option D. Methoxyflurane > Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide is the least potent and should be at the end of the sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is inversely proportional to their MAC values. Methoxyflurane, with the lowest MAC, is the most potent, while Nitrous oxide, with the highest MAC, is the least potent. The correct order of potency is Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > Nitrous oxide.

questions.text: Cardiac output can be determined using the following except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Capnography

 

Explanation:

 

Capnography primarily measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air, which gives information about ventilation and metabolism. It does not measure cardiac output. Capnography is commonly used to monitor end-tidal CO2 and confirm tracheal intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thermal dilution technique: The thermal dilution technique is a method used primarily with a pulmonary artery catheter (also known as a Swan-Ganz catheter). Cold saline is injected into the right atrium, and the change in blood temperature is measured as it passes a thermistor in the pulmonary artery. The degree of temperature change allows for the calculation of cardiac output. This method is invasive and provides continuous or intermittent measurements, depending on the specific catheter and monitor used.

 

Option C. Esophageal Doppler: The esophageal Doppler uses ultrasound waves to measure blood flow velocity in the descending aorta via a probe placed in the esophagus. By knowing the cross-sectional area of the aorta and calculating the velocity of blood flow, cardiac output can be estimated.

 

Option D. Echocardiography: Echocardiography, or cardiac ultrasound, allows for visualization of cardiac structures and blood flow. Cardiac output can be estimated by measuring the velocity of blood flow across the mitral or tricuspid valves and then multiplying this by the valve area.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Capnography measures the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air and is not used to determine cardiac output.

choices.text: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done.
High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used.
It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.
Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement in rapid sequence intubation? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.


Incorrect statement. Rapid sequence intubation typically involves administering an induction agent and a neuromuscular blocking agent to facilitate endotracheal intubation without the risk of aspiration. However, in cardiac arrest patients, the priority is to secure the airway quickly without delay. Often, these patients do not require medications for intubation as they are unresponsive and without protective reflexes. Also, chest compressions and defibrillation (if indicated) are of higher priority.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done:
Correct statement. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen before RSI helps to denitrogenate the lungs, ensuring that the patient has an adequate oxygen reserve during the apneic period (the time between paralysis and successful intubation). The goal is to delay the onset of hypoxemia during the apnea.

 

Option B. High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used:
Correct statement. A high-volume low-pressure cuff on the endotracheal tube distributes the pressure over a larger area of the tracheal mucosa. This minimizes the risk of tracheal injury or necrosis.

 

Option D. Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously:
Correct statement. In RSI, immediately after administering the induction agent (to render the patient unconscious), a neuromuscular blocking agent (muscle relaxant) is given to paralyze the patient, thus facilitating endotracheal intubation. This rapid administration of drugs is to minimize the time between loss of protective reflexes and securing the airway, hence reducing the risk of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Rapid sequence intubation is not the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients due to the need for immediate airway management and ongoing chest compressions, making drug administration less critical.

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift.

 

  • It is an airway management technique to open up the collapsed airway.
  • This maneuver involves tilting the patient's head backward by gently lifting the chin upward.
  • It is used to open the airway and clear any potential obstruction in the upper part of the throat.
  • This is a basic technique used in CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) to help with ventilation.

 

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: The jaw thrust maneuver is used to open the airway in a patient with a suspected cervical spine injury. Instead of tilting the head backward, the anesthesiologist uses their fingers to push the patient's jaw forward. This technique avoids movement of the neck and is often used when spinal injury is a concern.

 

 

Option C. Head extension: Head extension involves simply tilting the patient's head backward to open the airway. It is similar to the head tilt, chin lift maneuver, but it focuses more on extending the neck to clear the airway.

 

 

Option D. In line manual stabilization: This technique is used to stabilize the cervical spine, especially in cases of suspected neck injuries. It involves maintaining the head and neck in a neutral, aligned position to prevent further injury during maneuvers like intubation. This is typically done by an assistant while another healthcare provider performs airway management.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift.
  • It is an airway management technique to open up the collapsed airway.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked in the following local anesthesia technique shown in the image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasociliary nerve

 

  • Anatomy: The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).
  • Procedure: The needle is inserted 1 cm superior and 1.5 cm posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye. A maximum of 2 mL of local anesthetic solution is then slowly injected.
  • Use: This nerve block is used in procedures such as septoplasty, rhinoplasty, and the treatment of nasal bone fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal nerve: The anterior ethmoidal nerve is another branch of the ophthalmic nerve. It innervates the anterior and middle ethmoidal air cells and part of the nasal cavity, but it is not targeted by the described technique.

 

Option C. Sphenopalatine nerve: The sphenopalatine nerve, also known as the nasopalatine nerve, is a branch of the maxillary nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve). It supplies the nasal septum and the anterior part of the hard palate, but the described technique does not target this nerve.

 

Option D. Greater palatine nerve: The greater palatine nerve is also a branch of the maxillary nerve. It innervates the hard palate and the palatal gingiva, and is not targeted by the described technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nasociliary nerve block involves inserting a needle superior and posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye and injecting a local anesthetic solution. This technique is primarily used for procedures involving the nasal area, such as septoplasty, rhinoplasty, and nasal bone fracture treatment.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2413-2414

questions.text: Duration of action of Proparacaine? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 mins

 

Proparacaine:

 

  • Duration of Action: The duration of action of proparacaine is approximately 15-20 minutes.
  • Uses: Proparacaine hydrochloride is used as a topical anesthetic agent, especially for ophthalmic surgeries such as:
    • Tonometry
    • Gonioscopy
    • Removal of corneal foreign bodies
    • Short corneal and conjunctival procedures

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The duration of action of proparacaine is approximately 15-20 minutes, making it suitable for short ophthalmic procedures.

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 50 Hz

 

Explanation:

 

This is the frequency typically used for tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. A stimulation of 50 Hz for 5 seconds results in a tetanic contraction. If the patient is under profound neuromuscular blockade, no contraction will be observed. If there's some recovery from blockade, a contraction will be noted but may be weaker than in a patient with no blockade. Fade during or after tetanic stimulation can indicate incomplete recovery from blockade.

 

Tetanic stimulation is a method used in neuromuscular monitoring to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade in patients who have received neuromuscular blocking agents (often used during surgeries to produce muscle paralysis). Tetanic stimulation involves giving a high-frequency series of electrical impulses to a peripheral nerve to cause sustained muscle contraction. The response to tetanic stimulation can help determine the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the presence of fade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.2 Hz: This frequency is more representative of a "single twitch" stimulation, where one stimulus is delivered every 5 seconds. It is used to monitor the initial onset and the later stages of recovery from neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option B. 2 Hz: This refers to a train-of-four (TOF) stimulation where four stimuli are given at a frequency of 2 Hz (2 stimuli per second). It's a common method of monitoring neuromuscular blockade, especially when assessing for residual blockade. A fading response in the TOF is indicative of neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option C. 20 Hz: This isn't a standard frequency for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.

 

 

PATTERN OF NERVE STIMULATION:

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1359

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Well controlled asthma

 

Explanation:

 

Well controlled asthma: Asthma, when well controlled, should not significantly increase the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. Uncontrolled or poorly controlled asthma, on the other hand, would be a risk factor due to increased airway hyperreactivity and potential for bronchospasm or other complications in the postoperative period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BMI > 30: Obesity can reduce functional residual capacity and total lung volume, which increases the risk of atelectasis after surgery. Additionally, obese patients often have decreased diaphragmatic movement and may have associated conditions like obstructive sleep apnea, which can contribute to postoperative respiratory issues.

 

Option C. Upper abdominal surgery: Upper abdominal surgeries are associated with a higher risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. The diaphragmatic movement can be impaired after these surgeries, leading to decreased lung expansion and atelectasis, especially in the bases of the lungs. This can increase the chances of postoperative pneumonia and other respiratory issues.

 

Option D. Age > 70 years: Advanced age is a recognized risk factor for postoperative complications, including pulmonary complications. Older patients often have reduced physiological reserve, which means they have less ability to compensate for postoperative stress and changes in lung function. Furthermore, they are more likely to have comorbid conditions that can contribute to respiratory issues.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Well-controlled asthma is not a significant risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications, unlike other conditions such as obesity, upper abdominal surgery, and advanced age.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2591-2594

choices.text: Venous air embolism

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of laryngeal cancer is undergoing a modified radical neck dissection under general anesthesia. During the procedure, the patient is placed in a head-up position for better surgical access. Suddenly, the anesthesiologist notices a rapid drop in end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, accompanied by hypotension and new-onset cardiac arrhythmias. The surgeon reports that the internal jugular vein was being manipulated at the time of the event. What is the most likely cause of these intraoperative symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Venous Air Embolism

 

Explanation:

 

Venous air embolism is a serious intraoperative complication that occurs when air enters the venous circulation, typically during surgeries involving the head, neck, or chest, particularly when the patient is in a head-up position. Key indicators in this scenario include:

 

  1. Bleeding or manipulation of the internal jugular vein, which can act as an entry point for air;
  2. A sudden and significant drop in ETCO2 due to impaired pulmonary perfusion caused by the air obstructing pulmonary blood flow;
  3. Hypotension resulting from decreased venous return and right heart obstruction; and
  4. The use of a head-up position during neck surgery, which lowers venous pressure in the neck veins, facilitating air entry.

 

These findings strongly suggest venous air embolism, a condition requiring immediate intervention to prevent severe hemodynamic compromise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial infarction: While myocardial infarction can cause hypotension and arrhythmias, it would not present with a sudden drop in ETCO2. It typically manifests with chest pain, ECG changes, and elevated cardiac markers, none of which are associated with venous air embolism.

 

Option C. Anaphylactic reaction: Anaphylaxis might present with hypotension, tachycardia, and bronchospasm, but it often includes skin manifestations such as rash and flushing, along with airway swelling. It does not typically cause a rapid drop in ETCO2 due to pulmonary air obstruction.

 

Option D. Tension pneumothorax: Tension pneumothorax could cause hypotension and respiratory distress, but it is more often associated with decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on the affected side. It would not explain the sudden drop in ETCO2 seen in this case, which is more characteristic of venous air embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venous air embolism is a potential risk during surgeries involving manipulation of veins, especially in head-up positions. It presents with a sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and arrhythmias due to the air obstructing pulmonary blood flow. Recognizing these signs and promptly managing the embolism is essential to prevent significant hemodynamic compromise.

choices.text: Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse.
Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

questions.text: On your evening walk in the park, you notice an unconscious man lying on the ground. What would you do next? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

 

Explanation:

 

Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse: This is the recommended sequence in most bystander situations. Firstly, ensure scene safety (make sure you're not putting yourself or the individual in further danger). Then, call for help or ask someone nearby to do so. This ensures that professional medical help is on the way. After calling for help, you’d check the pulse and breathing. If the person is not breathing and/or doesn’t have a pulse, you would start CPR. If an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is available and the person doesn’t have a pulse, you would use it as soon as possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse: While checking the pulse and starting CPR is correct, calling for help first ensures that professional medical assistance is on the way, which is crucial for the best chance of survival.

 

Option C. Observe: This is not the recommended approach. Immediate intervention is critical when someone is unconscious, especially if they are not breathing or lack a pulse. Delays in initiating CPR or calling for help can drastically reduce the chance of survival and increase the potential for permanent injury.

 

Option D. Ignore and continue to walk: This is not an ethical or appropriate response when encountering someone in potential distress. Immediate action can make the difference between life and death.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In an emergency situation where someone is unconscious, the immediate steps should be to call for help, check for a pulse and breathing, start CPR if needed, and use a defibrillator if available and the person has no pulse.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2715-2716

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spontaneous respiratory effort

 

  • The capnograph shows a characteristic pattern known as the curare notch or curare cleft.
  • This pattern indicates spontaneous inspiratory effort by the patient during controlled mechanical ventilation.
  • This occurs when the patient attempts to breathe against the ventilator cycle, causing a dip in the capnograph waveform.
  • The appropriate next step would be to paralyze the patient again by administering an additional dose of muscle relaxant to ensure proper synchronization with the ventilator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal intubation: In cases of esophageal intubation, the capnograph typically shows a very low or absent end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) reading because the endotracheal tube is not in the trachea, leading to little to no CO2 being detected. The waveform would be almost flat.

 

 

Option B. Inspiration with cardiac oscillations: Cardiac oscillations can appear on the capnograph as small oscillations or ripples on the expiratory plateau due to the beating of the heart causing minor fluctuations in airway pressure. This is not characterized by a distinct cleft or notch.

 

 

Option C. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm causes a "shark fin" appearance on the capnograph due to obstructed airflow and prolonged expiration. The waveform would show a slanted, rather than a squared-off, expiratory plateau.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A curare notch or cleft on a capnograph indicates spontaneous respiratory effort in a patient who is supposed to be fully ventilated under muscle relaxants, requiring re-administration of the muscle relaxant to ensure proper mechanical ventilation.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1311

questions.text: Dr. Rajan is a consultant at a primary health center, frequently encountering cases of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and reproductive tract infections (RTIs). He usually prefers syndromic approach for managing these conditions due to limited diagnostic facilities. A 28-year-old male patient walks in, presenting with discharge from his urethra, indicating a possible urethritis. The patient is unaware of the specific causative organism. Given the syndromic management approach, which combination of medications would Dr. Rajan most likely prescribe to effectively treat both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cefixime + Azithromycin

 

  •  According to the syndromic approach for managing STIs/RTIs, the preferred treatment for both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis involves a combination of Azithromycin and Cefixime.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is seen in? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Psoriasis

 

Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is most commonly seen in psoriasis, which is a chronic inflammatory skin condition.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It is an inflammatory non-infectious disease characterized by an imbalance in T-cell subsets. There is an elevated number of activated Th1, Th17, and Th22 cells, while Th2 cells are deficient.

 

Cytokines in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Genetic predisposition: n Type 1 plaque psoriasis and guttate psoriasis with HLA C:06:02 association.
  • Around 5-30% of individuals with cutaneous psoriasis also develop psoriatic arthritis (PsA), a condition affecting the joints.
  • Psoriasis can affect the skin and joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
  • Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus:

  • Lichen planus can affect the nails and produce nail changes, but the common manifestations are nail thinning, ridging, or even complete loss of the nail.
  • Pterygium formation, where there's scarring of the cuticle area leading to the nail's progressive loss, can also be seen.
  • While lichen planus can cause nail pitting, it's typically not associated with subungual hyperkeratosis, a feature more consistent with psoriasis.

 

Option C. Vitiligo:

  • Vitiligo is a disorder where there's a loss of pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) leading to white patches on the skin.
  • It doesn't typically produce pitting of nails.

 

Option D: Alopecia areata:

Geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of the nails is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoriasis is the condition most commonly associated with irregular nail pitting and subungual hyperkeratosis among the options provided.

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 4.9, 35.4-35.34, 37.12, 41.1, 41.21 89.28-33

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

questions.text: Which of the following structures of the scapula is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The part of the scapula marked as "A" in this image is palpable and it is the coracoid process.

 

The apex of the coracoid process lies approximately 2.5cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa (deltopectoral triangle). Hence, the coracoid process can be palpated below the clavicle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B- Acromion process - Located at the top of the shoulder, this process forms the highest point of the shoulder and serves as an attachment for the clavicle and muscles of the shoulder. It is not palpable in the infraclavicular fossa.

 

Option C. C- Glenoid fossa - This is the socket part of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus to form the shoulder joint. It is not palpable externally due to its deep location.

 

Option D. D- Infraspinous fossa - A broad surface on the posterior aspect of the scapula, covered largely by the infraspinatus muscle. It is not palpable from the anterior aspect of the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The coracoid process (marked as A) is the scapular structure that can be palpated in the infraclavicular fossa, just below the clavicle. This palpation is useful for clinical assessments related to shoulder injuries and muscular attachments.

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: In a patient presented with a fever and a positive filarial antigen test, what is the next best step of management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

 

Given patient with fever and filarial antigen test positive points to diagnosis of filariasis. And the next best step for this patient is the detection of microfilariae in the blood smear.

 

The gold standard method to diagnose active infection is by demonstrating microfilariae in a blood smear by microscopy.

 

It is critical and should be based on the periodicity of the microfilariae. For nocturnal periodicity, blood should be collected between 9 pm and 2 am.

 

DEC provocation test is done to collect the blood in the day time. Patient takes a tablet of DEC orally (2mg/kg) so that the nocturnal microfilariae are stimulated and come to peripheral blood within 30 minutes.

 

Although there is an advantage of blood sample collection even during day time, the guidelines from CDC, NVBDCP, and IAPSM suggest blood sample collection at night, followed by identification of microfilariae in a blood smear by microscopic examination as the standard method for diagnosis.

 

Other methods to detect adult worms include:

 

  • Lymph node biopsy to detect adult worms.
  • X-ray (if worms are calcified)
  • High-frequency ultrasound and doppler of the scrotum (Option D).
  • Serology - Antigen detection by using monoclonal antibodies against Og4C3 and AD12 antigens.
  • ELISA and ICT

 

Treatment - Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) → DOC. Given orally in a dose of 6 mg per kg body weight daily for a period of 12 days. It kills microfilariae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone Marrow Biopsy: Not relevant for filariasis, as it does not involve the bone marrow.

 

Option B. DEC Provocation Test: While useful for driving microfilariae into the peripheral blood for easier detection during daytime, it is less direct than a nighttime blood smear.

 

Option D. Ultrasound of the Scrotum: Useful in chronic cases to detect adult worms in lymphatic vessels, particularly in cases of lymphatic filariasis affecting the scrotum, but not as immediate or definitive for acute diagnosis as a blood smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For direct confirmation of active filarial infection, detection of microfilariae in a blood smear is essential. This method provides clear evidence of the parasites in the bloodstream, crucial for diagnosing and managing filariasis effectively.

questions.text: All are reduced in Iron Deficiency Anemia except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TIBC

 

In Iron Deficiency Anemia, Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) is increased in order to compensate to the deficient state.

 

Iron deficiency anemia –

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin: Ferritin is an intracellular protein that stores iron and releases it in a controlled fashion. In IDA, ferritin levels drop as iron stores are exhausted.

 

Option C. Iron: Serum Iron reflects the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. In IDA, serum iron levels are reduced because iron stores are depleted.

 

Option D. Transferrin Saturation: This is the percentage of transferrin that is saturated with iron. In IDA, it is reduced because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DDs of microcytic anemia:-

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1231-1234

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease presents to you with chest pain and palpitations. The ECG is shown below. Which of the following can be used in the management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intravenous amiodarone

 

The ECG indicates a monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT), which is a type of fast heart rhythm originating from one of the ventricles. The appropriate management of stable monomorphic VT involves the use of intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia: This condition is characterized by a consistent QRS complex morphology on the ECG, suggesting a single focus of origin within the ventricles.
  • Stable vs. Unstable VT: For stable VT (where the patient does not exhibit hemodynamic instability such as hypotension, altered mental status, or severe chest pain), the initial treatment involves intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.
  • Intravenous Amiodarone: According to the Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) guidelines, intravenous amiodarone is a recommended first-line therapy for stable monomorphic VT. Other options include procainamide and sotalol, but amiodarone is widely used due to its efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral metoprolol: Oral metoprolol is not typically used in the acute management of monomorphic VT. Beta-blockers like metoprolol are more suitable for rate control in atrial arrhythmias or for long-term management of heart rate.

 

Option B. Oral amiodarone: While amiodarone is appropriate for treating VT, oral administration is not suitable for acute management due to the need for rapid onset of action, which intravenous administration provides.

 

Option D. Intravenous metoprolol: Although intravenous beta-blockers can be used in certain arrhythmias, they are not the first-line treatment for monomorphic VT. Intravenous amiodarone or other antiarrhythmics are preferred for their effectiveness in stabilizing the ventricular rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs such as amiodarone, procainamide, or sotalol are recommended as first-line treatments according to ACLS guidelines.

choices.text: Acetyl Co-A stimulation of pyruvate carboxylase
Fructose-1, 6-biphosphate stimulation of phosphofructokinase-1
Citrate stimulation of acetyl carboxylase
Fructose-2, 6-biphosphate stimulation of phosphofructokinase-2

questions.text: In conditions of starvation, which mechanism is most effective for gluconeogenesis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Acetyl Co-A stimulation of pyruvate carboxylase

 

Explanation:

 

 Acetyl Co-A is critical for gluconeogenesis, particularly during fasting when carbohydrate reserves are low. It acts as an allosteric activator of pyruvate carboxylase, an enzyme that converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate. This conversion is essential for maintaining glucose levels during fasting, as it facilitates the production of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. The presence of acetyl Co-A, derived from the breakdown of fatty acids, triggers these mechanisms, enhancing the gluconeogenic pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Fructose-1, 6-biphosphate stimulation of phosphofructokinase-1: This process is part of glycolysis, not gluconeogenesis, and acts in the opposite direction by promoting the breakdown of glucose.
  • Option C. Citrate stimulation of acetyl carboxylase: While citrate does stimulate acetyl carboxylase, this enzyme is involved in fatty acid synthesis, not gluconeogenesis.
  • Option D. Fructose-2, 6-biphosphate stimulation of phosphofructokinase-2: This stimulates glycolysis rather than gluconeogenesis and thus would not be effective in promoting glucose production during starvation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetyl Co-A is crucial for activating pyruvate carboxylase during gluconeogenesis, particularly in fasting states, helping to maintain glucose levels when dietary intake is low.

choices.text: Collagen is a type of fibrous protein, which is most abundant of all human proteins
Post translational hydroxylation of proline & lysine
Triple helix is required for its function

questions.text: Which of the following is false about collagen: (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most abundant AA is Phenyl-alanine

 

Collagen is a fibrous protein that is indeed the most abundant protein in the human body. It provides structural support to various tissues, including skin, bones, tendons, and blood vessels. However, the most abundant amino acid in collagen is actually glycine, not phenylalanine. Glycine makes up approximately one-third of the amino acids in the collagen protein chain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Collagen is a type of fibrous protein that is the most abundant protein in the human body. It forms a strong and flexible structure in various tissues.

 

Option C. Post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues is an essential process in collagen synthesis. This hydroxylation is necessary for the proper formation and stability of collagen's triple helix structure.

 

Option D. The triple helix structure is a characteristic feature of collagen and is crucial for its function. Collagen molecules are composed of three polypeptide chains, coiled around each other in a triple helical arrangement. This structure provides collagen with its strength and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the correct composition of collagen is essential to understand its structural role in the human body.

choices.text: Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase
Sensitivity will increase, specificity will decrease

questions.text: You are assessing the impact of a new series testing protocol on the performance characteristics of diagnostic tests for a specific disease. You need to explain to your team how this method affects the test's sensitivity and specificity. What would be the correct explanation? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase

 

SCREENING TESTS USED IN SERIES:

 

A population is subjected to one screening test followed by a second screening test; 2nd screening test is applied on those individuals only who test positive on the 1st screening test

 

  • Combined sensitivity of 2 tests A & B in series: Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B)
  • Combined specificity of 2 tests A & B in series: [Specificity (A) + Specificity (B)] – [Specificity (A) × Specificity (B)]

 

SCREENING TESTS USED IN PARALLEL:

 

A population is subjected to two (or more) screening tests at the same time; each of the individuals is subjected to both (or all) screening tests

 

  • Combined sensitivity of 2 tests A & B in parallel: [Sensitivity (A) + Sensitivity (B)] – [Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B)]
  • Combined specificity of 2 tests A & B in parallel: Specificity (A) × Specificity (B)

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Need for blood transfusion
Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS
Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS
Risk of peripartum hysterectomy

questions.text: A 39-year-old G6P2L1A3 presents with a history of previous 2 LSCS with PAS. What will you NOT counsel her about? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), the main risks include bleeding requiring transfusion, bladder injury, and possibly peripartum hysterectomy. Bowel injury is less commonly associated with PAS unless extreme or exceptional surgical complications occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Need for blood transfusion: It is common to counsel about the need for blood transfusion due to the high risk of hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS: Bladder injury is a significant risk if the placenta invades the bladder area.

 

Option D. Risk of peripartum hysterectomy: Peripartum hysterectomy may be necessary if the placenta is inseparable from the uterus.

 

Educational objective:

 

When counseling a patient with a history of previous cesarean sections and PAS, focus on the more likely complications such as significant bleeding, bladder injury, and the possibility of needing a hysterectomy, rather than bowel injury.

questions.text: A patient presented with paradoxical respiration. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. D

 

Explanation:

 

Paradoxical respiration occurs due to the damage of the phrenic nerve, which is marked as D, in the given image.

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

A. Right vagus nerve

B. Left vagus nerve

C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve)

D. Right phrenic nerve

 

 

The phrenic nerve provides motor innervation to the diaphragm, the primary muscle of inspiration. Damage or paralysis of one phrenic nerve can cause one hemidiaphragm to rise during inspiration instead of descending as it normally does, leading to paradoxical movement. This is especially noticeable when the patient is in a supine position. If the right phrenic nerve is affected, the right hemidiaphragm will exhibit this paradoxical movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve) has a broad distribution and is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of many organs in the thorax and abdomen. It also provides sensory innervation to the larynx, trachea, esophagus, and a portion of the external ear. It doesn't innervate the diaphragm directly for its motor function.

 

Option B. Left vagus nerve: Similarly to the right vagus, the left vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to many thoracic and abdominal organs but does not control diaphragmatic contractions.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve): This is a branch of the vagus nerve that innervates most intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is important for vocal cord function. Damage to this nerve can lead to hoarseness or voice changes but does not directly affect respiratory mechanics in the manner described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical movements in the chest are as follows:

 

  • Paradoxical respiration - the aberrant contraction of the abdomen or chest walls, which causes them to move in rather than out during inhalation. It appears in the flail chest.

 

Paradoxical movement of the diaphragm - Normally, during inspiration, the diaphragm descends. Yet, due to diaphragmatic paralysis in phrenic nerve palsy cases, the affected side of the diaphragm moves upward (paradoxical breathing). The gold standard test to find this is to stimulate the phrenic nerve electrically or magnetically while simultaneously recording the transdiaphragmatic pressure and/or the compound muscle action potential. Both fluoroscopy and ultrasonography can show this.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the vertex presentation with complete flexion attitude of head? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter

 

Explanation:

 

Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with a complete flexion attitude of the head.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suboccipito-frontal diameter:

 

  • This diameter measures about 10.5 cm and is seen when the head is only partially flexed.
  • It is not the smallest diameter and is not optimal for vertex presentations with complete flexion.

 

Option C. Occipito-frontal diameter:

 

  • This diameter measures approximately 11.5 cm and is seen in cases where the head is in a neutral position, neither fully flexed nor extended.
  • It is larger and more difficult for the passage of the fetal head through the birth canal.

 

Option D. Occipito-posterior position:

 

  • This is not a diameter but a fetal position where the back of the fetal head is directed towards the mother's back.
  • This position often leads to a more difficult labor and is associated with different presenting diameters, depending on the degree of head flexion or extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with complete flexion of the fetal head, facilitating easier passage through the birth canal.

 

Ref: Page no   92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Droplet digital PCR

questions.text: Best method for detection of mutations with low allele frequency is? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Droplet digital PCR

 

Option A. Droplet digital PCR : Digital Droplet PCR (ddPCR) is known as the third generation of quantitative PCR and is the Best method for detection of mutation with low allele frequency.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH): FISH is a cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes to bind to specific DNA sequences. While it is valuable for detecting chromosomal abnormalities, it may not be as sensitive as ddPCR for detecting mutations at low allele frequencies.

 

Option C. Nested PCR: Nested PCR involves two rounds of PCR amplification, with the second round using primers nested within the product of the first round. While it can increase sensitivity, it may not be as quantitative or precise as ddPCR.

 

Option D. Sanger Sequencing: Sanger sequencing is a traditional DNA sequencing method. While it is highly accurate, it may not be as sensitive as ddPCR for detecting low-frequency mutations. It is more suitable for identifying mutations present at higher allele frequencies.

 

Educational objective:

 

Droplet Digital PCR (ddPCR)

 

Principle: Droplet digital PCR is a highly sensitive and quantitative method for detecting and quantifying nucleic acids. It partitions the PCR reaction into thousands of droplets, and each droplet serves as an individual reaction chamber.

 

Advantages: It allows for absolute quantification of DNA with high precision and sensitivity. It is particularly effective in detecting mutations present at low allele frequencies.

 

Application: ddPCR is widely used for detecting rare mutations, monitoring minimal residual disease, and assessing low-abundance targets in various samples.

choices.text: i. = a, ii. = d, iii. = c, iv. = b
i. = b, ii. = c, iii. = a, iv. = d
