questions.text: Match the following? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. i. = c, ii. = a, iii. = d, iv. = b

 

i) Heroine = c) Brown sugar

 

ii) Joint = a) Ganja

 

iii) LSD = d) Acid

 

iv) Eve = b) Amphetamine

 

Explanation:

 

  • i. Heroin = c. Brown sugar
    • Heroin is a semi-synthetic opioid also known by street names such as brown sugar, smack, dope, junk.
  • ii. Joint = a. Ganja
    • A joint is a term used for a rolled marijuana cigarette. Ganja is also known as pot, grass, weed, rope, mull, dope, joint, Mary Jane, skunk, hash, reefer.
  • iii. LSD = d. Acid
    • LSD is known by various street names including acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, purple owle.
  • iv. Eve = b. Amphetamine
    • Methamphetamine and related substances are often referred to as Eve, meth, etc.

 

Educational Objective

 

Street names of narcotic substances

 

  • Ganja is called Pot, grass, weed, rope, mull, dope, joint, Mary Jane, skunk, hash, reefer.
  • Heroin is a semisynthetic opioid also known as brown sugar, smack, dope, junk
  •   Cocaine is called by names like snuff, Rock, Crack, Coke, Snow, Cadillac, White lady
  • Methamphetamine is also called eve, meth etc.
  • LSD is called by names like acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, purple Owle.
  • Abrus Precatorius is called by names like Indian liquor ice, prayer head, crab's eye, weather plant, gulagunchi, ratti, gunja.
  • Capsaicin is called by names like 'Hunan hand' as it causes burning of fingers.

questions.text: A female presented with loss of pain and temperature, but her touch sensation was intact. Imaging showed cavitation around the central canal. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Syringomyelia

 

Syringomyelia is characterized by the presence of a fluid-filled cavity or syrinx within the spinal cord, which typically expands over time. This condition most commonly affects the cervical and thoracic regions of the spinal cord. The classic presentation includes a loss of pain and temperature sensation in a "cape-like" distribution over the shoulders and back, while touch, vibration, and proprioception (posterior column sensations) remain intact. This pattern of sensory loss is due to the disruption of the decussating (crossing) fibers of the spinothalamic tract, which carry pain and temperature sensations. The cavitation around the central canal of the spinal cord is a hallmark of syringomyelia and leads to the aforementioned symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Brown-Sequard syndrome: This condition results from hemisection or damage to one half of the spinal cord. It typically presents with ipsilateral motor loss and loss of proprioception and vibration sense, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. This does not match the described symptoms and imaging findings.

 

Option B. Tabes dorsalis: This is a late manifestation of neurosyphilis, characterized by degeneration of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, leading to impaired proprioception and vibration sense, ataxia, and lightning pains. It does not cause cavitation around the central canal or the specific dissociated sensory loss seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Syringobulbia: This is a similar condition to syringomyelia but involves the brainstem (medulla oblongata) rather than the spinal cord. It presents with symptoms related to cranial nerve involvement such as dysphagia, dysarthria, and facial pain. The patient's symptoms and imaging findings are more consistent with syringomyelia, not syringobulbia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syringomyelia presents with a loss of pain and temperature sensation while preserving touch sensation, and is characterized by cavitation around the central canal of the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 41-year-old construction worker in Uttar Pradesh collapsed at the construction site in the afternoon of a summer day. Which of the following is least likely to be seen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sweating

 

The scenario describes a case of classic heat stroke, which is a medical emergency characterized by an elevated core body temperature (often above 104°F or 40°C) and central nervous system dysfunction due to exposure to high environmental temperatures.

 

Sweating is typically absent in classic heat stroke. This is because the body’s thermoregulatory mechanisms fail, and the skin becomes hot and dry. In contrast, in exertional heat stroke (which occurs during intense physical activity), sweating may still be present.

 

Other Options:

 

In classic heat stroke, particularly due to prolonged exposure to high environmental temperatures:

 

Option A. Temperature of 105°F: It is common to have very high body temperatures in heat stroke.

 

Option C. Hypotension: Can occur due to dehydration and vasodilation.

 

Option D. Tachypnea: Increased respiratory rate is a compensatory mechanism to help cool the body and deal with metabolic demands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In classic heat stroke, typically caused by high environmental temperatures, the patient often presents with high body temperature, hypotension, and tachypnea, but lacks sweating. This distinguishes it from exertional heat stroke, where sweating might still be present.

choices.text: Bone marrow aspirate
Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)
Polymerase chain reaction

questions.text: A 62-year-old elderly male presented with persistent fatigue and lymph total leucocyte count of 50,000/µl. His peripheral smear was done and had the findings as shown. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

The given history of elderly male with leucocytosis and the peripheral smear showing “smudge cells” is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The diagnosis of CLL can be confirmed using flow cytometry demonstrating cells with CD5/CD23 expression.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone marrow aspirate: While useful in some cases, it is not necessary for the initial diagnosis of CLL if flow cytometry can provide definitive results.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH is useful for detecting specific genetic abnormalities but is not the first step in confirming CLL.

 

Option D. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR can detect specific genetic mutations but is not typically used for the initial diagnosis of CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a suspected case of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), especially with the presence of smudge cells on a peripheral smear, flow cytometry is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.

questions.text: A male patient suffers a trauma and is being brought to the emergency room of a hospital. Since he needs an emergency lifesaving transfusion, which of the following can be safely transfused in him?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) O negative

 

In emergency situations where a lifesaving transfusion is needed, and there is no time to determine the patient's blood type, O negative blood is considered the universal donor and can be safely transfused to any patient. This is because O negative blood does not have any A, B, or Rh antigens on the surface of the red blood cells, minimizing the risk of an adverse reaction.

 

However, it is important to note that O negative blood is often in short supply. In extremely critical situations, such as with an older male or a postmenopausal female, or when O negative blood is not available, O positive blood may be used as an alternative. O positive blood can be safely transfused to males and females who are not of childbearing age, as the presence of Rh antigen can cause issues in future pregnancies for females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A positive: A positive blood type contains A and Rh antigens and can only be safely transfused to individuals with A positive, AB positive, or compatible types. It is not a universal donor.

 

Option B. AB negative: AB negative blood can only be given to AB negative or AB positive recipients due to the presence of both A and B antigens. It is also not a universal donor.

 

Option D. O positive: While O positive blood can be given in critical situations, it is not the first choice for universal emergency transfusions due to the presence of Rh antigen, which can cause complications in Rh-negative individuals, especially females of childbearing age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In emergency transfusion situations where blood type is unknown, O negative blood is the safest option due to its lack of A, B, and Rh antigens, making it universally compatible.

questions.text: Identify the following image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ranula

 

The given clinical scenario and the image showing a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth points to a diagnosis of a Ranula.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: A benign tumor made up of blood vessels, often appearing as a birthmark or red growth.

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: A fluid-filled sac that results from a blockage in the lymphatic system, often present at birth. It presents as a posterior neck swelling.

 

Option C. Branchial cyst: A congenital epithelial cyst that arises from remnants of the branchial arches, usually presenting as a neck lump.

questions.text: As the in-charge epidemiologist of an urban CHC, you've been reviewing the weekly infectious disease reports. In a particular community under your jurisdiction, you observe that dengue case counts typically range from 40 to 50 cases every week. During your current weekly review, you note there are 48 reported cases of dengue. Based on this data and your understanding of epidemiological terminology, how would you classify this week's situation with respect to dengue? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Endemic 

 

  • The given scenario is an example of an endemic disease.

 

Endemic

 

  • Endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent in a defined geographical area. It is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population
  • Types of Endemic:
    • Hyper-endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent at high incidence/prevalence AND affects all age groups equally
    • Holo-endemic: A high level of infection beginning early in life AND affecting most of the children population

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidemic: Incorrect because an epidemic refers to an increase in the number of cases of a disease beyond what is normally expected in that population in that area. The current case count does not exceed the usual range.

 

Option C. Sporadic: Incorrect because sporadic refers to a disease that occurs infrequently and irregularly; here, the cases are neither infrequent nor irregular.

 

Option D. Outbreak: Similar to an epidemic, an outbreak implies a greater-than-anticipated increase in the number of cases within a small, localized area over a short period. Again, since the case count is within normal expectations, this term does not apply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endemic: Is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population

choices.text: Colorectal carcinoma
Breast Carcinoma
Pancreatic carcinoma
Ovarian carcinoma

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presented to her doctor with abdominal pain and fatigue. Further investigations, including imaging tests and biopsies, led to a diagnosis of metastatic liver adenocarcinoma. The tumor markers showed CK7 (-), CK20 (+), and CDX-1 (+), IC markers. Based on this what is the most common site of primary tumor origin? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colorectal carcinoma

 

The tumor marker profile with CK7 (-), CK20 (+), and CDX-2 (+) is indicative of a colorectal carcinoma origin. CK20 is commonly expressed in colorectal cancer, and the negative CK7 helps to differentiate it from other adenocarcinomas which might also express CK20 but are usually CK7 positive, such as those from the pancreas or ovary. The expression of CDX-2 further supports this origin, as CDX-2 is a marker highly specific for gastrointestinal tract adenocarcinomas, particularly those arising from the colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast Carcinoma: Typically would show positive CK7 and negative CK20 and CDX-2.

 

Option C. Pancreatic Carcinoma: Often shows CK7 positivity and variable CK20 and rarely expresses CDX-2.

 

Option D. Ovarian Carcinoma: Commonly CK7 positive, CK20 negative, and does not usually express CDX-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the utility of tumor markers CK7, CK20, and CDX-2 in identifying the primary origin of metastatic adenocarcinoma, particularly their roles in diagnosing colorectal carcinoma when metastatic to the liver.

choices.text: 5-alpha reductase

questions.text: Finasteride is used to treat male-pattern baldness acts by inhibiting which of the following enzymes?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5-alpha reductase

 

5-α Reductase is the enzyme that helps in the conversion of Testosterone into its active form Dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This is implicated in the causation of Androgenetic Alopecia or the male-pattern baldness. Finasteride is the drug that works by inhibiting the 5-α Reductase enzyme within the hair follicle, thereby preventing the male pattern hair loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aromatase: Aromatase is the enzyme which converts androgens into estrogens. This enzyme is inhibited by Aromatase inhibitors which are Letrozole, Anastrozole and Exemestane

 

Option B. 17-hydrolase: 17-hydrolase is the enzyme which is involved in Steroid biosynthesis. It is present in Adrenals and Ovaries.

 

Option D. Phosphodiesterase: Phosphodiesterase metabolize cGMP and cAMP. It is inhibited by PDE inhibitors like Theophylline (non-specific), Milrinone (PDE-3) and Sildenafil (PDE-5) etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Finasteride treats male-pattern baldness by inhibiting the enzyme 5-alpha reductase, which prevents the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), the hormone responsible for hair follicle miniaturization in androgenetic alopecia. This targeted inhibition helps in slowing hair loss and promoting hair regrowth.

choices.text: 6 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 12 months
7 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 5 months
4 drugs for 4 months followed by 6 drugs for 10-12 months
5 drugs for 6 months followed by 4 drugs for 12 months

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). According to the World Health Organization's guidelines, which of the following treatment schedules is recommended? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 7 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 5 months

 

  • WHO defines Multi-drug resistant (MDR) Tuberculosis strain as Resistant to INH and Rifampicin with or without resistant to other anti TB drugs

 

Treatment of MDR-TB:

 

  • DOTS PLUS (Older name: Category IV)
  • Must be done on basis of sensitivity testing
  • Directly observed therapy certainly helps to improve outcomes and is considered an integral part of MDR-TB treatment
    • The recommended treatment regimen for multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) involves a two-phase approach.
    • In the initial phase, patients are prescribed a combination of seven drugs for a duration of 4 to 6 months. These seven drugs are collectively referred to as CHOBZEE, which stands for Clofazimine, High dose Isoniazid, Levofloxacin, Bedaquiline, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol, and Ethionamide.
    • Following the initial phase, the treatment enters a second phase where four drugs are continued for an additional 5 months. These four drugs are collectively known as COZE, consisting of Clofazimine, Levofloxacin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol. Note: Bedaquiline is always given for 6 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

New Regimens for Treatment Drug Resistant TB (RNTCP 2017-18)

 

 

(Drugs: Hh: High dose isoniazid; E:Ethambutol; Z:Pyrazinamide; K:Kanamycin; Cm: Capreomycin; A Amikacin; L: Levofloxacin; M: Moxifloxacin; Mh: High dose moxifloxacin; Et; Ethionamide; Cs: Cycloserine; Cz: Clofazimine; Lz: Linezolid; Bq: Bedaquiline

questions.text: An experiment is being conducted on a dog blood pressure to study the effect of acetylcholine. The blood pressure is recorded at each intervention and is shown below. What does phase 4 in the graph indicate? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Nicotinic action of acetylcholine

 

For demonstrating nicotinic actions (on ganglia) of acetylcholine, two criteria are required:

 

  • High dose of acetylcholine (around 5 mg).
  • Muscarinic receptors must be blocked by giving atropine (to avoid death of the animal due to overactivity of muscarinic receptors)

 

About the given graph:

 

 

  • In phases 1 and 2, Acetylcholine is given at doses of 2 mcg and 50 mcg. This leads to a drop in the BP due to its action in the muscarinic receptors.
  • In phase 3 when its muscarinic action is blocked by atropine, administration of 50 mcg of Acetylcholine does not cause a fall in BP.
  • But in phase 4, when Ach is administered at higher dose of 5 mg, it acts on the Neuronal Nicotinic receptors located in CNS, ganglia and adrenals, leading to their stimulation and release of norepinephrine, which causes the BP to shoot up. Thus, Phase 4 in the graph indicates the nicotinic action of acetylcholine at higher doses.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Muscarinic action of acetylcholine: Muscarinic actions are demonstrated in Phases 1 and 2, where acetylcholine causes a drop in blood pressure. This option is incorrect for Phase 4.

 

Option B. Potentiation of acetylcholine: Potentiation would suggest an increased effect due to repeated or combined actions, which is not the primary mechanism demonstrated in Phase 4.

 

Option C. Antagonism of acetylcholine: Antagonism would imply inhibition of acetylcholine’s effects. Phase 3 demonstrates antagonism (by atropine) but not Phase 4.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase 4 in the graph indicates the nicotinic action of acetylcholine, characterized by a rise in blood pressure due to the stimulation of neuronal nicotinic receptors after administering a high dose of acetylcholine (5 mg) following the blockade of muscarinic receptors with atropine.

choices.text: Transferrin saturation
RBC protoporphyrin
Total iron binding capacity
Serum transferrin receptors

questions.text: In iron deficiency anemia all of the following is increased except? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transferrin saturation

 

Transferrin Saturation: This is the percentage of transferrin (the protein that transports iron in the blood) that is saturated with iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the transferrin saturation is decreased because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin.

 

It is important to note that in a patient with iron deficiency anemia, there is increased TIBC as well as increased RBC Protoporphyrin levels and the number of serum transferrin receptors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC protoporphyrin: This is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway. In iron deficiency anemia, the lack of iron means that protoporphyrin accumulates, as it cannot be converted into heme. Therefore, RBC protoporphyrin levels are increased.

 

Option C. Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): This is a measure of the total capacity of the blood to bind iron with transferrin. In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased as the body produces more transferrin in an attempt to capture more iron from the diet and the body’s stores.

 

Option D. Serum transferrin receptors: These receptors are present on the surface of cells and are involved in the uptake of transferrin-bound iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the number of these receptors increases as the body tries to increase iron uptake from the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Calcium channel blocker

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diuretic

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above the target levels despite the use of three antihypertensive agents of different classes, one of which should be a diuretic. This is because diuretics, typically thiazide diuretics, help to reduce blood volume and are effective in lowering blood pressure. Including a diuretic ensures optimal blood pressure control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers are used but are not specifically required for the diagnosis of resistant hypertension.

 

Option B. Beta blockers: Beta blockers are also commonly used but not specifically required for the definition.

 

Option C. Alpha blockers: Alpha blockers may be used as part of the treatment regimen but are not specifically required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for resistant hypertension include having blood pressure above target despite taking three drugs, one of which must be a diuretic, OR having controlled blood pressure with four or more drugs. Typically, a thiazide diuretic is used in the setting of hypertension.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma
  2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination
  3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection
  4. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Statements 1, 3 and 4 are true.

 

1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma: This is true. Mammography is an essential tool in the early detection of breast cancer, but it has been associated with over-diagnosis. As a result, some women might receive unnecessary treatment for non-life-threatening tumors.

 

2. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection: This is true. Visual inspection of the oral cavity can detect precancerous lesions or early signs of oral cancer. Regular dental check-ups often include a visual check for signs of oral cancer.

 

3. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear: This is true. A Pap smear (or Pap test) is a procedure to test for cervical cancer in women. The test involves collecting cells from the cervix to be examined under a microscope to detect abnormalities that can turn into cervical cancer.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination: This statement is not entirely accurate. While a digital rectal examination (DRE) can detect some abnormalities or tumors in the rectum, it is not the primary method for colon cancer screening. The primary methods for colon cancer screening include fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, and colonoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates.
  2. Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy.
  3. Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality.
  4. Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test.
  5. Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs promotes bone formation? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Teriparatide
 

  • Teriparatide is recombinant PTH analogue that is used in the treatment of osteoporosis. When given in low doses, it stimulates bone formation by mimicking the physiological action of PTH on the osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Calcitonin: Mechanism: Calcitonin inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption. It helps maintain bone density but does not stimulate new bone formation.

 

Options B. Raloxifene: Mechanism: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It inhibits bone resorption by reducing osteoclast activity and is used to prevent bone loss in postmenopausal women, but it does not promote bone formation.

 

Options C. Bisphosphonates: Mechanism: Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate and risedronate, inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. These drugs help maintain bone density and reduce the risk of fractures, but they do not promote new bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS USED IN OSTEOPOROSIS

questions.text: Graft from identical twin is called: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isograft

 

An isograft is a type of graft where the donor and the recipient are genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of graft has the lowest risk of rejection because the donor and recipient have the same genetic makeup, which means their tissues are immunologically compatible.

 

Types of Grafts:

 

Option A. Allograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of the same species but have different genotypes.
  • Examples: Organ transplants between two different individuals (e.g., kidney transplant from one person to another non-twin individual).

 

Option B. Autograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are the same person.
  • Examples: Skin grafts taken from one part of the body and transplanted to another part of the same individual's body.

 

Option C. Isograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft between two individuals who are genetically identical, such as identical twins.
  • Examples: Organ or tissue transplants between identical twins.

 

Option D. Xenograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of different species.
  • Examples: Transplantation of animal tissues or organs into humans, such as pig heart valves used in human heart surgery.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Autografts are grafts in which both the donor and the recipient are the same person.
  • Isografts are grafts that occur between donors and recipients who share the same genotype. An isograft is a graft from an identical twin
  • Allografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of the same species but of a different genotype.
  • Xenografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of different species.

choices.text: 2 minutes of spontaneous breathing with a face mask
3 minutes of tidal volume breathing through a face mask
4 deep breaths over 30 seconds
5 minutes of normal breathing through nasal cannula

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the preoperative evaluation, the anesthesiologist emphasizes the importance of preoxygenation to ensure adequate oxygen reserves during the intubation process. The patient is positioned comfortably and provided with 100% oxygen. Which of the following is the recommended duration or technique for effective preoxygenation before tracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 3 minutes of tidal volume breathing through a face mask

 

Explanation:

 

The recommended method for effective preoxygenation involves having the patient breathe 100% oxygen through a tight-fitting face mask for 3 minutes using tidal volume breathing. This technique replaces the nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen, increasing the body’s oxygen reserve and extending the safe apnea period during tracheal intubation. The primary goal of preoxygenation is to maximize oxygen saturation and prolong the time before hypoxemia occurs, providing the anesthesiologist with a critical window to secure the airway safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 minutes of spontaneous breathing with a face mask: This duration is insufficient for optimal preoxygenation, as it may not completely replace the nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen, resulting in inadequate oxygen reserves during apnea.

 

Option C. 4 deep breaths over 30 seconds: Although taking four deep breaths over 30 seconds can help increase oxygen levels, it is not as effective as the standard 3 minutes of tidal volume breathing. This technique is sometimes used when time is limited but does not provide the same level of safety.

 

Option D. 5 minutes of normal breathing through nasal cannula: Preoxygenation with a nasal cannula is less effective than a face mask due to the lower inspired oxygen concentration and potential for room air entrainment, leading to suboptimal preoxygenation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Effective preoxygenation before tracheal intubation is best achieved by having the patient breathe 100% oxygen through a tight-fitting face mask for 3 minutes using tidal volume breathing. This process replaces lung nitrogen with oxygen, extending the safe apnea time and enhancing patient safety during airway management

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bcl-2

 

The anti-apoptotic factor among the following is BcI-2.

 

Apoptosis is a process of programmed cell death that occurs in multicellular organisms. It is a highly regulated process that involves a complex network of proteins and signaling pathways. Among the proteins involved in apoptosis are two families of proteins known as the Bcl-2 family and the caspase family.

 

The Bcl-2 family of proteins includes both pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members. The pro-apoptotic members include Bax, Bak, and others, while the anti-apoptotic members include Bcl-2, Bcl-XL, and others. The balance between pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family is important in determining whether a cell will undergo apoptosis or not.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P-53: P-53 is a tumor suppressor protein known for its role in preventing cancer. It can induce apoptosis but is generally considered a promoter of cell cycle arrest and DNA repair in response to DNA damage, rather than being anti-apoptotic.

 

Option B. K-ras: K-ras is an oncogene that, when mutated, contributes to cancer progression by promoting cellular proliferation and survival, not directly inhibiting apoptosis.

 

Option D. BAK: BAK, like Bax, is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family. It promotes apoptosis by facilitating mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization, which is a critical step in the activation of the apoptotic pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bcl-2's anti-apoptotic properties make it a key player in cellular survival and stress response. Its ability to inhibit key steps in the apoptotic process distinguishes it from other proteins like P-53, K-ras, and BAK, which have different roles in the regulation of cell death and proliferation.

questions.text: As a public health expert, you are consulted about a series of outbreaks in a region that lacks significant prior vaccination campaigns. Given the imperative to contain the spread of disease and protect vulnerable populations, you are asked to prioritize a disease for which mass vaccination would provide the most immediate and impactful reduction in transmission. Which of the following diseases would most benefit from such an intervention? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Polio

 

  • Mass immunization is one of the best strategies to deal with outbreak of poliomyelitis.
  • Outbreak response immunization (ORI): Following the Acute flaccid paralysis case investigation and stool specimen collection, ORI is organized in community.
  • Children aged 0-59 months are given one dose of OPV regardless of previous immunization (in the village/locality of the AFP case)
  • Travel history of the child with AFP may suggest additional places of stay where ORI should also be conducted
  • Atleast 500 children are vaccinated

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cholera: In case of a cholera outbreak, the most effective response would be chemoprophylaxis for a household or a closed community and. Drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis is Tetracycline.

 

Option B. Typhoid: control in case of an outbreak includes health education, water quality and sanitation improvement, prevent carriers from handling food, milk or water from others, and training of health professionals in diagnosis and treatment. Vaccination is not advised for typhoid outbreaks.

 

Option D. Tetanus: Tetanus is not a communicable disease in the traditional sense as it does not spread from person to person. Instead, it is caused by bacteria entering the body through wounds. Thus, mass vaccination for tetanus isn't typically utilized as an outbreak response but is important in routine immunization schedules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polio, due to its potential for rapid spread and severe outcomes, along with the availability of an effective and easily administered vaccine, makes it the most critical focus for a mass vaccination campaign in response to an outbreak.
  • This strategy not only protects individuals but also aids in the global effort to eradicate polio.

 

Additional Information

 

Outbreak response for Measles includes

 

  1. Isolation for 7 days after the onset of rash
  2. Immunization of the contacts within 2 days of exposure (if vaccine is contraindicated, immunoglobulins should be given within 3-4 days of exposure)
  3. Prompt immunization at the beginning of an epidemic is essential to limit the spread.

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency with overdose some drug. There were increased salivation and increased bronchial secretions. On examination, blood pressure was 88/60 mmHg. RBC esterase level is 50. What should be the treatment of this person?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atropine

 

  • Low esterase levels are suggestive of overdose of some drug which acts by inhibiting acetyl choline esterase like organophosphate poisoning.
  • Inhibition of choline esterase results in increased amount of Ach at synapse, so poisoning or overdose results in cholinergic symptoms like salivation, lacrimation, urination, emesis, increased bronchial secretions, and reduction in blood pressure.
    So treatment of choice is Atropine.
  • Atropine - It is highly effective in counter-acting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects. It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action. All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly treated with atropine 2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear (upto 200 mg has been administered in a day). Continued treatment with maintenance doses may be required for 1-2 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is incorrect as it is an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor, which would worsen the cholinergic symptoms by increasing acetylcholine levels further.

 

Option C. Flumazenil: Flumazenil is incorrect because it is an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, not for organophosphate poisoning. It works by antagonizing the effects of benzodiazepines on the central nervous system.

 

Option D. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is incorrect as it is also an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor, which would exacerbate the symptoms of cholinergic overdose. Additionally, it is used to treat atropine poisoning, not organophosphate poisoning.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of organophosphate poisoning, which presents with cholinergic symptoms and low RBC esterase levels, the treatment of choice is atropine, administered intravenously until signs of atropinization appear.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/122

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

  • The image shows Codfish Vertebra seen in Osteoporosis.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is characterized by presence of bony defect at pars interarticularis, which can result in spondylolisthesis. Most common vertebra having spondylolysis is L5. High incidence of spondylolysis in gymnasts and other athlete’s suggest repetitive injury, which may be the contributing mechanism. Patient aged over 50 years are usually women. They always have backache or sciatica and claudication due to spinal stenosis. On examination, buttocks look flat, the sacrum appears to extend to the waist and transverse loin creases are seen. Step off can be felt when the fingers are run down the spine, secondary to prominent spinous processes of L5. With more severe slippage, the lumbosacral junction becomes more kyphotic and the trunk appears shortened with the rib cage approaching the iliac crest. Percentage of slippage as measured on lateral view and oblique radiograph demonstrate collar or broken neck on the scottie dog in spondylolysis.

 

 

Collar or broken neck on the scottie dog appearance

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis is the forward slippage of one vertebrae upon another. It nearly always occurs between L5 and S1 (most common) or L4 and L5. Patient aged over 50 years are usually women. They always have backache or sciatica and claudication due to spinal stenosis. The extent of slippage may not be correlated with severity of pain. On examination, buttocks look flat, the sacrum appears to extend to the waist and transverse loin creases are seen. Step off can be felt when the fingers are run down the spine, secondary to prominent spinous processes of L5. With more severe slippage, the lumbosacral junction becomes more kyphotic and the trunk appears shortened with the rib cage approaching the iliac crest. Percentage of slippage is measured on lateral view and oblique radiograph demonstrate beheaded dog in spondylolisthesis (Beheaded Scottish terrier sign).

 

 

Beheaded dog appearance

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis. It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. The bone contains increased number of osteoclasts but these do not resorb bone as evidenced by absence of ruffled borders and clear zones and are unable to respond to PTH. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease). Malignant osteopetrosis (congenital form) is autosomal recessive (AR, 11q13) and late onset osteopetrosis tarda (adolescence/adult form) is AD (1P 21). Intermediate form is AR. Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is diagnosed in adult asymptomatic patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Autosomal recessive malignant osteopetrosis presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth, resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. Fragile, brittle bones, and Pathological fractures are seen. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen on radiograph. Treatment is bone marrow transplant.

 

 

 

Marble bone appearance

 

 

Rugger jersey spine

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is the radiological feature seen in osteoporosis, called as codfish appearance of vertebra.

questions.text: Which part of the internal capsule is affected in hemiplegia due to ischemic stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior Limb

 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule is the most commonly affected area in cases of hemiplegia due to ischemic stroke. This area carries the corticospinal tract, which is essential for motor control. When the posterior limb is compromised, it disrupts the corticospinal pathway, leading to muscle weakness or paralysis on the opposite side of the body from the lesion.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: Primarily involved in visual processing. Damage here would likely lead to visual field defects rather than motor dysfunction.

 

Option B. Anterior limb: Primarily associated with cognitive and emotional functions due to its connectivity between the thalamus and the frontal lobe. Lesions here generally do not cause hemiplegia.

 

Option C. Sublentiform: Involved in auditory and gustatory pathways, thus unrelated to motor control functions affected in hemiplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ischemic stroke, damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in hemiplegia because of the disruption of corticospinal tracts. This knowledge aids in accurate stroke localization and informs rehabilitation strategies to help regain motor functions.

choices.text: Complete transection of spinal cord
Ipsilateral loss of vibration & touch
Contralateral loss of pain & temperature

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complete transection of spinal cord

 

A complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome. A complete transection would result in loss of all motor and sensory functions below the level of the injury on both sides of the body, which is different from the hemisection seen in Brown-Séquard syndrome.

 

Brown-Séquard syndrome results from a hemisection or partial lesion of the spinal cord, typically affecting one half. This syndrome is characterized by a distinct pattern of neurological deficits due to the disruption of different spinal cord tracts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ipsilateral loss of vibration & touch: This occurs because the posterior columns (dorsal columns) are affected, leading to loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch on the same side as the lesion.

 

Option C. Contralateral loss of pain & temperature: This results from the damage to the spinothalamic tract, which crosses to the opposite side of the spinal cord. Therefore, pain and temperature sensations are lost on the side opposite to the lesion.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral loss of proprioception: Like the loss of vibration and touch, proprioception is also affected ipsilaterally due to involvement of the posterior columns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown-Séquard syndrome is characterized by hemisection of the spinal cord, leading to ipsilateral loss of vibration, touch, and proprioception, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature. Complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of this syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following calculates one variable using another variable? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of Regression

 

Coefficient of Regression can be used to calculate one variable using another variable.

 

The Coefficient of Regression is a statistical measure that assesses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. It is used to predict or estimate the value of one variable based on the value of another variable.

 

For example, in a regression analysis, we may want to predict a person's weight based on their height. In this case, height would be the independent variable and weight would be the dependent variable. The coefficient of regression would help us determine the relationship between these variables and enable us to make predictions about a person's weight based on their height.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Coefficient of Correlation:  Measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables.

 

Option C.  The Coefficient of Variation: Is a measure of the relative variability of a dataset.

 

Option D. The Coefficient of Determination: Is a measure that determines the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is explained by the independent variable in a regression analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Regression is used to calculate or predict the value of one variable based on the value of another variable, quantifying the relationship between the independent and dependent variables in regression analysis.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Gestational hypertension

questions.text: A baby was born at 34 weeks of pregnancy; the appearance of the baby is given below. What is the mother suffering from? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a large for gestational age (LGA) fetus. Macrosomia is a condition where a newborn baby is significantly larger than average. This can often be identified by a higher birth weight and size compared to typical babies born at the same gestational age.

 

Causes of Macrosomia:

 

  1. Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) and Overt Diabetes Mellitus:
    • Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia, which stimulates insulin production in the fetus. Insulin acts as a growth hormone, leading to increased fetal growth and fat deposition.
  2. Maternal Obesity:
    • Increased maternal body mass index (BMI) is associated with a higher risk of delivering a macrosomic baby.
  3. Previous Baby with Macrosomia:
    • A history of delivering a large baby increases the risk of subsequent babies also being large.
  4. Post-term Pregnancy:
    • Pregnancy extending beyond the due date increases the chance of the baby growing larger.
  5. Excessive Weight Gain in Pregnancy:
    • Significant maternal weight gain during pregnancy contributes to larger fetal size.

 

Conditions Not Associated with Macrosomia:

 

  • Anemia and Antepartum Hemorrhage (APH): These conditions are typically associated with fetal growth restriction rather than macrosomia.
  • Thrombocytopenia: This condition has no direct association with fetal weight.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Rubella: Rubella infection during pregnancy can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which is typically associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), not macrosomia.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism: Maternal hypothyroidism can lead to complications such as preterm birth and low birth weight but is not directly linked to macrosomia.

 

Option D. Gestational Hypertension: Gestational hypertension is associated with IUGR and preterm birth rather than increased fetal size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational diabetes is a significant risk factor for macrosomia, leading to the birth of large for gestational age (LGA) babies.

 

Ref: Page no 2169, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
